body.p: IASC decided to reject the ‘permanent’ criterion because:

li.p: it is difficult to identify whether an impairment loss is permanent. There is a risk that, by using this criterion, recognition of an impairment loss may be delayed.

this criterion is at odds with the basic concept that an asset is a resource that will generate future economic benefits. Cost‑based accrual accounting cannot reflect events without reference to future expectations. If the events that led to a decrease in recoverable amount have already taken place, the carrying amount should be reduced accordingly.
